lead_paragraph: If you look at our cover this week and think maybe you have enough worries in your life without adding anthrax back to the list, I completely understand. I feel that way myself sometimes. But I urge you to at least read the first section of Wil Hylton's story about the state of bioterrorism preparedness - it's only 400 words - and I'll be surprised if you don't feel compelled to keep going. Yes, you'll be a little freaked. Maybe a lot freaked. But Wil's reporting isn't just about the nightmarish scenarios that could befall us. It's about what exactly the U.S. government has been up to since the anthrax attacks in the wake of 9/11, and the shocking extent to which we have wasted precious time and billions of dollars on poorly defined policy objectives and bureaucratic logjams. This is not merely bad news. This an exposé that ought to inspire a rethinking of the entire program.

headline.main: This Sunday: Excuse Me While I Get Fitted for a Hazmat Suit
